contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox scientist |name = Karol Borsuk |image = <!--(filename only)--> |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1905|5|8}} |birth_place = [[Warsaw]], [[Congress Poland|Poland]], [[Russian Empire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1982|1|24|1905|5|8}} |death_place = Warsaw, [[People's Republic of Poland|Poland]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = Polish |ethnicity = |fields = [[Mathematics]] |workplaces = |alma_mater = [[Warsaw University]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Stefan Mazurkiewicz]] |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = [[Samuel Eilenberg]]<br>[[Krystyna Kuperberg]] |known_for = [[Borsuk's conjecture]]<br>[[Borsuk–Ulam theorem]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |signature = <!--(filename only)--> |footnotes = }} '''Karol Borsuk''' (May 8, 1905 – January 24, 1982) was a [[Poland|Polish]] mathematician. His main interest was [[topology]]. Borsuk introduced the theory of ''absolute retracts'' (ARs) and ''absolute neighborhood retracts'' (ANRs), and the [[cohomotopy group]]s, later called Borsuk–[[Edwin Spanier|Spanier]] cohomotopy groups. He also founded the so called [[Shape theory (mathematics)|Shape theory]]. He has constructed various beautiful examples of topological spaces, e.g. an acyclic, 3-dimensional continuum which admits a fixed point free homeomorphism onto itself; also 2-dimensional, contractible polyhedra which have no free edge. His topological and geometric conjectures and themes stimulated research for more than half a century. Borsuk received his [[master's degree]] and [[doctorate]] from [[Warsaw University]] in 1927 and 1930, respectively; his [[Ph.D.]] thesis advisor was [[Stefan Mazurkiewicz]]. He was a member of the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]] from 1952. Borsuk's students included [[Samuel Eilenberg]], [[Krystyna Kuperberg]], [[Włodzimierz Kuperberg]], and [[Jerzy Dydak]]. ==See also== * [[Borsuk's conjecture]] * [[Borsuk–Ulam theorem]] * [[Zygmunt Janiszewski]] * [[Stanislaw Ulam]] * [[Scottish Café]] * [[Animal Husbandry (game)|Animal Husbandry]], an educational [[dice game]] published by Borsuk at his own expense in 1943 during the [[German occupation of Warsaw]]. ==Works== * ''Geometria analityczna w n wymiarach'' (1950) * ''Podstawy geometrii'' (1955) * ''Foundations of Geometry'' (1960) with Wanda Szmielew, North Holland publisher * ''Theory of Retracts'' (1966) * ''Theory of Shape'' (1975) == External links == *{{MacTutor Biography|id=Borsuk}} *{{MathGenealogy |id=12548}} {{Authority control|VIAF=56738244}} <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]] --> {{Persondata |NAME= Borsuk, Karol |ALTERNATIVE NAMES= |SHORT DESCRIPTION=Polish mathematician |DATE OF BIRTH= 1905-5-8 |PLACE OF BIRTH= [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] |DATE OF DEATH= 1982-1-24 |PLACE OF DEATH= Warsaw, Poland }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Borsuk, Karol}} {{Poland-mathematician-stub}} [[Category:Polish mathematicians]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:Topologists]] [[Category:Members of the Polish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:University of Warsaw alumni]] [[Category:University of Warsaw faculty]] [[Category:People from Warsaw]] [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]]
